Jackie Lindauer (1932-1992) | children = }} '''Susan Lindauer''' (born 17 July 1963) is an [[United States|American]] journalist, author, and antiwar activist. She was accused of conspiring to act as an agent for the [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]] and engaging in prohibited financial transactions involving the government of Iraq under [[Saddam Hussein]]. Lindauer was found [[Competence (law)|mentally unfit]] to stand trial and all charges were dropped in 2009. ==Personal life== She is the daughter of [[John Howard Lindauer II]], the newspaper publisher and former Republican nominee for [[Governor of Alaska]]. Susan's mother was Jackie Lindauer (1932-1992) who died of cancer in 1992. In 1995 her father married Dorothy Oremus, a Chicago attorney who along with other members of her family owned the largest cement company in the Midwest.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Ex-journalist in spy case unfit for trial |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/379317_iraqspy17.html|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=September 16, 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-26 }} Lindauer is also a [[second cousin]] of former [[White House Chief of Staff]] [[Andrew Card]].Lindauer, Susan (2011-02-17) [http://www.lewrockwell.com/orig12/lindauer1.1.1.html Tea Party Crashes: The Most Unpatriotic Act], ''[[LewRockwell.com]]'' ==Education and employment== Lindauer attended [[East Anchorage High School]] in [[Anchorage, Alaska]] where she was an honor student and was in school plays.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Suspect is remembered as worldly |url=http://dwb.adn.com/front/story/4841671p-4779085c.html |work=[[Anchorage Daily News]] |date=March 13, 2004 |accessdate=2009-01-26 }} She graduated from [[Smith College]] in 1985. She earned a [[masters degree]] in [[public policy]] from the [[London School of Economics]]. She worked as a temporary reporter at the ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' for 13 weeks in 1987, and as an editorial writer at the ''The Everett Herald'' in [[Everett, Washington]] in 1989. She then was a reporter and researcher at ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' in 1990 and 1991.{{cite news |first= James|last= Dao|authorlink= |coauthors= |title= An Antiwar Activist Known for Being Committed Yet Erratic |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9804E0DF103EF931A25750C0A9629C8B63 ||newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=March 12, 2004 |accessdate=2008-06-11 }}{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Neighbor Seemed Activist, Not Agent |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/ac2/wp-dyn/A51972-2004Mar11?language=printer |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |date=March 12, 2004 |accessdate=2009-01-26 }} Her co-workers said she was a woman "prone to mood swings and erratic behavior". She then worked for Representative [[Peter DeFazio]], [[United States Democratic Party|D]]-[[Oregon]] (1993) and then Representative [[Ron Wyden]], [[United States Democratic Party|D]]-[[Oregon]] (1994) before joining the office of Senator [[Carol Moseley Braun]], [[United States Democratic Party|D]]-[[Illinois]], where she worked as a press secretary and speech writer. == Activism == Susan Lindauer claims she started making visits to the Libyan Mission to the [[United Nations]] in 1995, and that she held meetings with [[Iraqi Intelligence Service]] officials at the [[United Nations]] in 1999. [[Andrew Card]] is her second cousin. Her first contact with the former [[Chief of Staff]] to President [[George W. Bush]] was around 2001. On January 8, 2003, she delivered a letter to Card urging the White House to not invade Iraq.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Ex-Congressional Aide Accused of Working With Iraqi Intelligence Before War |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F02E4DC103EF931A25750C0A9629C8B63|work=[[New York Times]] |date=March 12, 2004 |accessdate=2008-06-11 | first1=Richard W. | last1=Stevenson | first2=Eric | last2=Lichtblau}} ==Arrest== Lindauer was arrested on Thursday, 11 March 2004 in [[Takoma Park, Maryland]] and charged with "acting as an unregistered agent of a foreign government". The indictment alleged that she accepted US$10,000 from Iraqi intelligence services in 2002. Lindauer denies receiving the money, but admits taking a trip to Baghdad.{{cite news |first= David|last= Samuels|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Susan Lindauer's Mission To Baghdad |url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=980DE2DC143EF93AA1575BC0A9629C8B63 |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=August 29, 2004 |accessdate=2008-11-07 }} She was released on [[bail bond|bond]] on March 13, 2004 to attend an arraignment the following week.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Suspect in Iraq Spy Case Released. Lindauer, a Takoma Park Antiwar Activist, to Be Arraigned Monday. |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-154325.html |work=[[Washington Post]] |date=March 13, 2004 |accessdate=2009-01-26 }} In 2005 she was incarcerated in [[Carswell Air Force Base]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]] for [[psychological evaluation]] then moved to the [[Metropolitan Correctional Center]] in Manhattan. == Unfit to stand trial == In 2006, she was released from prison after [[Michael B. Mukasey]] ruled that Lindauer was unfit to stand trial and could not be forced to take [[antipsychotic medication]] to make her competent to stand trial.{{cite news |first= Anemona|last= Hartocollis|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Ex-Congress Aide Accused in Spy Case Is Free on Bail |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/09/nyregion/09spy.html|work=[[New York Times]] |date=September 9, 2006 |accessdate=2009-01-26 }} In 2008, [[Loretta A. Preska]] of the Federal District Court in [[New York City]] reaffirmed that Lindauer was mentally unfit to stand trial.{{cite news |first= Benjamin|last= Weiser|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Woman Accused of Iraq Ties Is Ruled Unfit for Trial Again |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/17/nyregion/17lindauer.html|work=[[New York Times]] |date=September 16, 2008 |accessdate=2009-02-06 }} On January 16, 2009 the government decided to not go ahead with the prosecution saying "prosecuting Lindauer would no longer be in the interests of justice."{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Case Dropped Against Md. Woman |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/01/16/AR2009011604599.html |newspaper=[[Washington Post]] |date=January 17, 2009 |accessdate=2010-12-29 }}{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Case dropped against aide accused of helping Iraq |url=http://www.foxnews.com/wires/2009Jan16/0,4670,IraqSpyCase,00.html |newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |date=January 16, 2009 |accessdate=2010-12-29 }} == Media== Lindauer has written a book "Extreme Prejudice: The Terrifying Story of the Patriot Act and the Cover-Ups of 9/11 and Iraq" about her experience.{{cite web | first=Susan|last=Lindauer|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Extreme Prejudice |url=http://extremeprejudiceusa.wordpress.com/|accessdate=2010-12-01 }} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=17352362648182906720&q=susan+lindauer&hl=en&as_sdt=40000003 United State of America vs. Susan Lindauer] *[http://extremeprejudiceusa.files.wordpress.com/ Susan Lindauer's book website] {{Persondata | NAME = Lindauer, Susan | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = July 17, 1963 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lindauer, Susan}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the London School of Economics]] [[Category:American journalists]] [[Category:People from Anchorage, Alaska]] [[Category:Smith College alumni]] [[Category:American public relations people]] [[Category:American spies]] [[Category:Iraqi spies]]
